docs.lead_paragraph: As a teenager growing up in Belmont, Mass., Erin Mahony was, in her mother's words, ''tilted like a teapot.'' Because of a curvature of the spine called scoliosis, Erin's right shoulder was several inches higher than the left, she limped and her left arm hung down so low that her hand could touch her foot. Unlike most youngsters with scoliosis, whose condition first becomes apparent around the time of puberty, Erin was born with a spinal deformity that made three operations and many years of bracing necessary. But today, at 23, she stands straight without a brace, skis, plays tennis and hikes. She is a first-year medical student at Yale, with hopes of becoming a pediatrician.

headline.main: Tips for Staying a Step Ahead of Scoliosis

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on scoliosis, spinal deformation that afflicts youngsters, girls more often than boys; says early detection is critical; photo; drawing (M)
